title: Moses I. Cantine (politician)
text:
Moses I. Cantine (January 18, 1774 - January 24, 1823) was an American politician, judge and newspaper editor from <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>. A <a href="Democratic-Republican%20Party">Democratic-Republican</a>, he was most notable for his service as a member of the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Senate">New York State Senate</a> and First Judge of the <a href="Greene%20County%2C%20New%20York">Greene County</a> Court.
Biography.
Cantine was born in <a href="Marbletown%2C%20New%20York">Marbletown</a>, <a href="Ulster%20County%2C%20New%20York">Ulster County, New York</a> on January 18, 1774, a son of Johannes and Maria (Brodhead) Cantine. He graduated from <a href="Princeton%20University">Princeton University</a> in 1796, <a href="reading%20law">studied law</a>, was <a href="Admission%20to%20the%20bar%20in%20the%20United%20States">admitted to the bar</a>, and practiced in <a href="Greene%20County%2C%20New%20York">Greene County, New York</a>.
A member of the <a href="Democratic-Republican%20Party">Democratic-Republican Party</a>, Cantine served as district attorney of the Third District (<a href="Columbia%20County%2C%20New%20York">Columbia</a>, <a href="Greene%20County%2C%20New%20York">Greene</a> and <a href="Rensselaer%20County%2C%20New%20York">Rensselaer</a> counties) from 1805 to 1806, 1808 to 1810, and 1811 to 1818. He served in the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Senate">New York State Senate</a> from 1814 to 1818. He served as First Judge of the Greene County Court from 1818 to 1820.
A longtime member of the <a href="New%20York%20Army%20National%20Guard">New York Militia</a>, Cantine served as inspector of the 4th Brigade with the rank of <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a>. During the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>, he served on the northern frontier, the border area between <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> and <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. In 1818, he was appointed the militia's judge advocate general with the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>.
On August 25, 1820, Cantine and <a href="Isaac%20Q.%20Leake">Isaac Q. Leake</a> took over the "Albany Argus" from <a href="Jesse%20Buel">Jesse Buel</a>. In addition to publishing the newspaper, Cantine and Leake received appointment as the official state printers.
He died in <a href="Albany%2C%20New%20York">Albany, New York</a> on January 24, 1823. Contemporary news accounts indicate that Cantine died after drinking <a href="Cr%C3%A8me%20de%20Noyaux">Crème de Noyaux</a>. This <a href="liqueur">liqueur</a> contains trace amounts of <a href="hydrogen%20cyanide">hydrogen cyanide</a>, and bottles left to age will sometimes have the poison concentrate near the top, posing a risk to the person who takes the first drink after the bottle is opened.
Family.
Cantine was married to Christina Hoes (1780-1823), the sister of <a href="Martin%20Van%20Buren">Martin Van Buren</a>'s wife <a href="Hannah%20Van%20Buren">Hannah</a>. They were the parents of two children, Moses Jr. and Christina.
